res: Let $S$ be a set of $9$ lattice points (points with integer coordinates) in $3$-dimensional Euclidean space. Prove that there exists a lattice point along the interior of some line segment that joins two distinct points in $S$.

Translating: Let $S$ be a set of $9$ lattice points (points with integer coordinates) in $3$-dimensional Euclidean space. Prove that there exists a lattice point along the interior of some line segment that joins two distinct points in $S$.

res.content: You are a Mathematics, Lean 4 and coding assistant who answers questions about Mathematics and Lean 4, gives hints while coding in Lean 4. You also translates from natural language to Lean Theorem Prover code and vice versa when asked. Follow EXACTLY any examples given when generating Lean code.

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: If three points lie in the affine span of two points, those five points are collinear. 

Give ONLY the Lean code

‚àÄ {k : Type u_1} {V : Type u_2} {P : Type u_3} [inst : DivisionRing k] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup V] [inst_2 : Module k V]
  [inst_3 : AddTorsor V P] {p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ p‚ÇÑ p‚ÇÖ : P},
  p‚ÇÅ ‚àà affineSpan k {p‚ÇÑ, p‚ÇÖ} ‚Üí
    p‚ÇÇ ‚àà affineSpan k {p‚ÇÑ, p‚ÇÖ} ‚Üí p‚ÇÉ ‚àà affineSpan k {p‚ÇÑ, p‚ÇÖ} ‚Üí Collinear k {p‚ÇÅ, p‚ÇÇ, p‚ÇÉ, p‚ÇÑ, p‚ÇÖ}

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: This theorem states that given a triangle in an affine space over a field with a linear order and no zero divisors, if there are two lines from distinct vertices of the triangle to interior points of the opposite sides and these lines intersect at a point `p`, then `p` lies strictly between the vertex and the point on the opposite side. The theorem is symmetric, meaning it holds true for either segment from a vertex to the point on the opposite side.

Give ONLY the Lean code

‚àÄ {R : Type u_1} {V : Type u_2} {P : Type u_4} [inst : LinearOrderedRing R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup V]
  [inst_2 : Module R V] [inst_3 : AddTorsor V P] [inst_4 : NoZeroSMulDivisors R V] {t : Affine.Triangle R P}
  {i‚ÇÅ i‚ÇÇ i‚ÇÉ : Fin 3},
  i‚ÇÅ ‚â† i‚ÇÇ ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p : P},
      Sbtw R (t.points i‚ÇÇ) p‚ÇÅ (t.points i‚ÇÉ) ‚Üí
        Sbtw R (t.points i‚ÇÅ) p‚ÇÇ (t.points i‚ÇÉ) ‚Üí
          p ‚àà affineSpan R {t.points i‚ÇÅ, p‚ÇÅ} ‚Üí p ‚àà affineSpan R {t.points i‚ÇÇ, p‚ÇÇ} ‚Üí Sbtw R (t.points i‚ÇÅ) p p‚ÇÅ

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem:  Given three collinear points in a Euclidean space, if two points lie on a sphere and the distance of the third point (not on the sphere) to the sphere's center is less than the sphere's radius, then the third point strictly lies between the other two points on the sphere.

Give ONLY the Lean code

‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] {s : EuclideanGeometry.Sphere P} {p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ : P},
  Collinear ‚Ñù {p‚ÇÅ, p‚ÇÇ, p‚ÇÉ} ‚Üí p‚ÇÅ ‚àà s ‚Üí dist p‚ÇÇ s.center < s.radius ‚Üí p‚ÇÉ ‚àà s ‚Üí p‚ÇÅ ‚â† p‚ÇÉ ‚Üí Sbtw ‚Ñù p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: In a three-dimensional space, given a tetrahedron with vertices `x`, `y`, `p`, `q`, a segment `[u, v]` that joins the opposite edges `[x, p]` and `[y, q]`, and a triangle formed by the vertices `p`, `q`, and `z` where `z` lies on the line segment `[x, y]`, this theorem states that the segment `[u, v]` is not disjoint from the convex hull of the triangle `{p, q, z}`. In other words, the line segment `[u, v]` must intersect or pass through the interior of the triangle `{p, q, z}`.

Give ONLY the Lean code

‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} [inst : LinearOrderedField ùïú] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E] [inst_2 : Module ùïú E]
  {p q u v x y z : E},
  z ‚àà segment ùïú x y ‚Üí u ‚àà segment ùïú x p ‚Üí v ‚àà segment ùïú y q ‚Üí ¬¨Disjoint (segment ùïú u v) ((convexHull ùïú) {p, q, z})

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem:  In Euclidean geometry, given a sphere and two points on it with one point inside and the other not outside, the second point lies on the straight line segment connecting the first point and the point of intersection of the line passing through the first and second points and the sphere.

Give ONLY the Lean code

‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] {s : EuclideanGeometry.Sphere P} {p p' : P},
  p ‚àà s ‚Üí dist p' s.center ‚â§ s.radius ‚Üí Wbtw ‚Ñù p p' (s.secondInter p (p' -·µ• p))

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: The **Minkowski Convex Body Theorem for compact domain**. If `s` is a convex compact symmetric
domain of `E` whose volume is large enough compared to the covolume of a lattice `L` of `E`, then it
contains a non-zero lattice point of `L`. Compared to
`exists_ne_zero_mem_lattice_of_measure_mul_two_pow_lt_measure`, this version requires in addition
that `s` is compact and `L` is discrete but provides a weaker inequality rather than a strict
inequality. 

Give ONLY the Lean code

‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : MeasurableSpace E] {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure E} {F s : Set E} [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]   [inst_2 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_3 : BorelSpace E] [inst_4 : FiniteDimensional ‚Ñù E] [inst_5 : Nontrivial E]   [inst_6 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsAddHaarMeasure Œº] {L : AddSubgroup E} [inst_7 : Countable ‚Ü•L]   [inst_8 : DiscreteTopology ‚Ü•L],   MeasureTheory.IsAddFundamentalDomain (‚Ü•L) F ‚Üí     (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, -x ‚àà s) ‚Üí       Convex ‚Ñù s ‚Üí IsCompact s ‚Üí ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº F * 2 ^ FiniteDimensional.finrank ‚Ñù E ‚â§ ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº s ‚Üí ‚àÉ x, x ‚â† 0 ‚àß ‚Üëx ‚àà s

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: This theorem states that for a collinear set of points (a set of points all lying on the same straight line) in an affine space over a division ring, if a point is a member of this set and is distinct from two other points in the set, then this point is contained within the affine span of those two other points. In other words, in a collinear set, any point can be expressed as a linear combination of any two other distinct points from the set.

Give ONLY the Lean code

## Theorem:  In an affine space over a field with a linear order and no zero divisors, if there are two lines from distinct vertices of a triangle to interior points of the opposite sides that intersect at a point, then this point lies strictly between the vertex and the point on the opposite side.

  {i‚ÇÅ i‚ÇÇ i‚ÇÉ : Fin 3},
  i‚ÇÅ ‚â† i‚ÇÇ ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p : P},
      Sbtw R (t.points i‚ÇÇ) p‚ÇÅ (t.points i‚ÇÉ) ‚Üí
        Sbtw R (t.points i‚ÇÅ) p‚ÇÇ (t.points i‚ÇÉ) ‚Üí

Translate the following statement into Lean 4:
## Theorem: This theorem states that in a Euclidean geometry, any three distinct points (p‚ÇÅ, p‚ÇÇ, p‚ÇÉ) from a cospherical set S (a set of points that are all equidistant from some center point) are affinely independent. Affinely independent points are such that no non-trivial weighted subtraction (where the sum of weights equals zero) equals zero. In other words, these three points do not lie on the same straight line in the space defined by the geometry.

Give ONLY the Lean code

‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]

  EuclideanGeometry.Cospherical s ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ : P}, p‚ÇÅ ‚àà s ‚Üí p‚ÇÇ ‚àà s ‚Üí p‚ÇÉ ‚àà s ‚Üí p‚ÇÅ ‚â† p‚ÇÇ ‚Üí p‚ÇÅ ‚â† p‚ÇÉ ‚Üí p‚ÇÇ ‚â† p‚ÇÉ ‚Üí AffineIndependent ‚Ñù ![p‚ÇÅ, p‚ÇÇ, p‚ÇÉ]
